> > > It's farily straight forward to repair, you can tell what
> conductor
> > > goes to what conductor on the board. It's just a matter of making
> > > little jumpers with small wire to bridge the breaks. Radio shack
> has
> > > #30 wire wrap wire that works well for that kind of stuff. Maybe
> > > there's enough of the original pad left on the connectors that you
> > > could glue them back in place, then jumper the breaks. I could
> look
> > > at it tomorrow, as well.
> > >
> > >
> >
> >
> > > There's a green coating on the circuit traces called solder
> mask,
> > > you'll have to very gently scrap some of the mask off to solder
> on a
> > > jumper wire. You'll see the copper colored conductor under the
> mask.
> > > Then you aplly some solder to conductor, and some to the wire,
> then
> > > heat the two togther to join them. Watch out for solder bridges
> > > between conductors.
> > >

> > > > > > photographed every step of the way and taped screws and
> parts
> > > to the
> > > > > > photos so we'd know how to rebuild everything we took

> > > > > that
> > > > > > has worked just fine. I located the IR filter, removed it

> > > cut

> > > > > > if so, what type of glue to use, or if we're just plain up

> > > > > > hoping someone out there can give us some advice, or if you
> live
> > > > > near
> > > > > > Highlands Ranch, CO, you could help in person & bail us out
> of
> > > > > this. I
> > > > > > was hoping to take this camera to the St. Augustine
> Lighthouse
> > > at
> > > > > the
> > > > > > end of this coming week.

> > > the
> > > > > > clips (one is pink, the other is ivory) and the damaged

> > > > > had

> > > > > time
> > > > > > (that's why it looks that way). For an idea of scale, the
> clips
> > > are
> > > > > > both the same size, about 4 mm in width, 4 mm tall, 3 mm
> deep.
> > > Not
> > > > > > easy to handle and even harder to see with these middle age
> > > eyes.
